(2 comments)
are you planning to add more to the commit log? .Looking at the changes it is doing something else too to handle invalid callback handler. How does it relate to cancel?

Yes, I will add more to the commit message, I was just looking for an early indication of whether this overlaps with any of the work you were doing.  Yes, cancel is probably not the best name for the commit.
FYI, this is the important part of the change.  We're now always reading from the socket, so we see disconnects faster.

do we care about sendinprogress and recieveinprogress state now?
What happens receive timer expires before server gets time to process the request? Now both send and receiver share same start time. Or uses only the receiver timer expiry because sender timer should be cancelled for receiver timer.

I see what you mean;  I removed the recieveInProgress state in the latest patch now that we're always receiving.


> What happens receive timer expires before server gets time to process the request?

That's a good point, and something I didn't think about.  Please take a look at how I've rearranged the timer.

what happens to sendinprogress state?
dont we have mutiple outstanding async op in parallel?
I'm not sure I understand what you mean by the sendinprogress state.  Yes, we will have one receive op and one send op in progress at a time.  That's allowed.
this was the repeat of above comment . you have addressed the flag management in the above commit
Good. This previous log always confuses me

when do this happen? will not the callback shares the lifetime of connectioninfo?
valid call back is always assigned to connection info in sendData
In the case where the connection disconnects, but didn't have an active request in progress.

A general comment. Is there any plan to rewrite the http-client using coroutine?. I can see that a coro-task implementation is available with sdbusplusplus library. The nested call back in http_client is always a burden for refactor/review.

I would fully support a rewrite of http client using c++20 coroutines, but I don't plan on doing that myself.

If that's something you're interested in doing, feel free to send me patches.  asio supports c++20 coroutines, so it should be pretty doable, just time and effort.
can we give better log here too? aync_wait failed is very generic.
What would you prefer here?
something that talks about timer explicitly. async_wait is confusing as we don't know if the connection is broken or not.
Please tell me what text you would like here, and I will update it.
retry timer wait failed?
do we need timeout? Can't we keep receive indefinitely ? other timeouts will anyway closes the connection so that receive will be interrupted and new connection starts as usual.

I think if we're not expecting a response, we can receive indefinitely until we hit a TCP timeout.  If we're waiting on a response, we don't want to be waiting forever on a hung webserver.  We'd rather retry faster than waiting for TCP to timeout if somehow the connection went away.

I thought we made this change to achieve two things. 
1) to get the response from server. 
2) to monitor any possible break in the connection. 
1 is already achieved by existing implementation
2 is what we were targeting with this patch set. 
Is it correct?

> 2 is what we were targeting with this patch set.

Yep.
#2 was the only thing I was trying to achieve
then why we need a timer to cancel the monitoring? let the monitoring continue forever till there is a tcp timeout or explicit connection termination by server

because if we're in the middle of waiting for a server to reply, we want a much shorter timeout than TCP.  TCP timeout is much longer than we want (on the order of minutes).

The intent is esentially
If we're waiting for a reply, set a 30 second timeout.
if we're not waiting for a reply, let TCP determine our timeout.

but line 355 will return in case of timer expiry and there is no more monitoring for the connection termination right?

How do we make sure that we don't want to wait for replay from server but will wait wait for connection termination?
Line 355 would only fire in the case where bmcweb is being shut down and the object is being destroyed.
On timer expiry Line 513,shutdownConn(true) will be called right? That will not cause 355?
Yes, that's true, shutdownConn would cause that as well, but I don't think that's a problem in this case?  Restarting would restart the read?

yes, there is no technical problem there. My question was do we really want to restart? 
for eg: in case of redfish events, it is ok if server does not send back any response. In this case just monitoring for server disconnect will do the job. Since we are waiting asynchronously a server hang may not have much impact.

> Since we are waiting asynchronously a server hang may not have much impact.

Server hang may be alright for redfish events, but it would have an impact on Redfish aggregation.  We can't return the overall response until either we receive a response from the satellite BMC or we timeout/fail in the connect->send->receive flow.  The timeout at least helps mitigate that.

> The intent is esentially
> If we're waiting for a reply, set a 30 second timeout.
> if we're not waiting for a reply, let TCP determine our timeout.

This sounds reasonable to me since it preserves the current aggregation behavior.

> In this case just monitoring for server disconnect will do the job

That's effectively what we're doing by using the Read.

@Carson ,True. I did not think about the case where read response is a must. 
My concern was that if we wanted to monitor the sever disconnect , we need an event to be sent first. Then after time out the monitoring is stopped. So we are not effectively monitoring the server disconnect beyond the timeout time.

> So we are not effectively monitoring the server disconnect beyond the timeout time.

In this patchset, we're always monitoring the connection.
How? After the read is aborted we are not reading again right(line 355) ?
since we have two outstanding IO, what happens both fails(a common scenario). Would the retry code execute multiple times? How do we avoid that ?
I don't think this one can execute twice, because it's only ever started once.
I mean both afterWrite and afterRead will be called and hence the code inside that will executed twice. That means waitAndRetry will be called twice.
afterWrite and afterRead do different things though.  Which code exactly will be executed twice?
line 312 and line 367 will not execute concurrently?
You're right, 367 is wrong, it should be checking to see if we have a request in flight before returning.
